## Frequentist calibration

- Confidence interval (freq): 
  - For any fixed parameter value, $x\%$ CI contains the true value $x\%$ of the time.
  - Worst case
  - Usually (conservative) approximation

## Bayesian calibration

- Credible interval (Bayes)
  - Averaged over the prior, $x\%$ CrI contains the true value $x\%$ of the time.
  - Specific values may lead to low coverage
  - Usually exact*

## Other inference goals

### Frequentist Test = inverted confidence interval

### Bayes factor = calibrated posterior model probability

:::{.notes}
We can more or less convert everything into confidence/credible interval

## It is hard to be a frequentist! 

### (with [exact]{.highlight1} [finite-sample]{.highlight1} guarantees)

- Exact freq computation is _very hard_
- Freq properties hard to exhaustively check
- Bayesian computation can be verified ([SBC](https://doi.org/10.1214/23-BA1404), [Yao et al.](https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14593))

:::{.notes}
Freq. properties cannot be exhaustively checked empirically
Bayesian computation can be (SBC + Yao approach)

If we both do Laplace approximations, is there any difference?
:::

Inferences on derived quantities, prediction intervals
